questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bile secretion. Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that inhibits parasympathetic stimulation by blocking muscarinic receptors (M1, M2, M3). It effectively reduces secretions in various glands such as salivary, gastric, intestinal, and pancreatic glands. However, bile secretion is primarily controlled by hormonal regulation (cholecystokinin, secretin) and liver function, rather than direct parasympathetic stimulation. Since atropine does not significantly affect bile production by hepatocytes, it does not reduce bile secretion. Incorrect Options (False Statements): (A) HCl secretion – False Atropine inhibits gastric acid (HCl) secretion by blocking M1 receptors on gastric parietal cells. This reduces vagal stimulation of acid production but is not the primary mechanism of acid suppression (proton pump inhibitors are more effective). (C) Intestinal secretions – False Intestinal secretions, including mucus and digestive enzymes, are partly regulated by parasympathetic activity. Atropine blocks M3 receptors, leading to reduced intestinal secretions and motility, which can cause constipation. (D) Pancreatic secretions – False The pancreas receives parasympathetic stimulation via the vagus nerve, which promotes enzymatic and bicarbonate secretion. By blocking muscarinic receptors, atropine decreases pancreatic exocrine secretions. However, hormonal control (secretin, CCK) still plays a role, so the reduction is not absolute.

Correct Answer (D) All of the above. Topical atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that blocks M3 receptors in the eye, leading to multiple effects: Mydriasis (Pupil Dilation) – Atropine blocks parasympathetic stimulation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, allowing the dilator pupillae muscle (sympathetic control) to dominate, resulting in pupil dilation (mydriasis). Abolition of Light Reflex – Since the light reflex depends on parasympathetic activation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, atropine-induced mydriasis prevents pupillary constriction in response to light, leading to abolition of the light reflex. Corneal Anesthesia – Atropine reduces tear secretion and impairs corneal sensation, leading to corneal dryness and anesthesia with prolonged use. Incorrect Options (False Statements): None of the options are incorrect, as all of them are valid effects of atropine when applied topically in the eye.

Correct Answer (B) Preventing motion sickness. Scopolamine hydrochloride is a muscarinic antagonist that primarily acts on the vestibular system and vomiting center (CTZ - chemoreceptor trigger zone) in the brainstem. It blocks M1 receptors, reducing the effects of vestibular disturbances that trigger motion sickness. It is most effective when used prophylactically (before symptoms start), making it a preferred preventive agent rather than a treatment. Scopolamine is commonly administered via transdermal patches applied behind the ear several hours before travel, providing long-lasting protection against motion sickness. Incorrect Options: (A) Treating motion sickness – Incorrect, because scopolamine is most effective when used before symptoms begin. Once motion sickness sets in, it becomes less effective in relieving symptoms. (C) Both A and B – Incorrect, because while scopolamine is effective before motion sickness starts (prevention), it is not as effective in treating established symptoms. (D) None of the above – Incorrect, because scopolamine is clinically used for preventing motion sickness.

questions.text: What is the most dangerous effect of belladonna in very young children?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hyperthermia. Belladonna (Atropa belladonna) contains atropine and scopolamine, which are anticholinergic agents that block muscarinic receptors. In young children, the most dangerous effect of belladonna toxicity is severe hyperthermia (high body temperature). This occurs due to inhibition of sweat gland activity (anhidrosis), leading to impaired heat dissipation. Infants and young children are particularly susceptible because they have a higher surface area-to-body mass ratio and immature thermoregulatory mechanisms, making them prone to rapid overheating. If untreated, hyperthermia can cause seizures, organ failure, and death. The classic symptoms of belladonna toxicity follow the mnemonic: "Hot as a hare (hyperthermia), Dry as a bone (anhidrosis), Red as a beet (flushing), Blind as a bat (mydriasis), Mad as a hatter (hallucinations and delirium)". Incorrect Options: (B) Dehydration – Incorrect, though belladonna causes dry mouth and reduced secretions, dehydration is not the most immediate or life-threatening effect. Hyperthermia is far more critical in young children. (C) Hallucination – Incorrect, while hallucinations and delirium are common with anticholinergic toxicity, they are not the most dangerous effect. Hyperthermia poses a greater risk of mortality. (D) Hypertension – Incorrect, as belladonna toxicity usually causes tachycardia but not severe hypertension. The primary cardiovascular effects are increased heart rate (tachycardia) and decreased secretions, rather than high blood pressure.

questions.text: A drug 'X' belongs to the anticholinergic drug group. It is primarily used in pre anesthetic medication and also during surgery. Which of the following can be 'X'?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Glycopyrrolate. Glycopyrrolate is a quaternary ammonium anticholinergic drug that is widely used in pre-anesthetic medication and during surgery. It works by blocking muscarinic receptors, leading to reduced salivation, bronchial secretions, and gastric acid secretion. This makes it highly effective in preventing aspiration and airway obstruction during anesthesia. Additionally, glycopyrrolate does not cross the blood-brain barrier, so it lacks central anticholinergic effects (e.g., sedation or confusion), making it safer for surgical use than some other anticholinergics. Incorrect Options: (A) Pipenzolate methyl bromide – Incorrect, because it is mainly used as an antispasmodic for treating gastrointestinal disorders rather than for pre-anesthetic purposes. (B) Isopropamide – Incorrect, as it is a long-acting anticholinergic primarily used in peptic ulcer treatment due to its ability to reduce gastric acid secretion. It is not commonly used in anesthesia. (C) Dicyclomine – Incorrect, since it is an antispasmodic drug mainly used to treat irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and abdominal cramps rather than for surgical or anesthetic applications.

choices.text: Exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye
Exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses

questions.text: The difference between hyoscine and atropine is that hyoscine
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses. Hyoscine (Scopolamine) and Atropine are both anticholinergic drugs derived from belladonna alkaloids, but they differ in their effects on the central nervous system (CNS). Hyoscine readily crosses the blood-brain barrier and has a stronger CNS depressant effect than atropine, even at low doses. This leads to sedation, drowsiness, and amnesia, which makes hyoscine particularly useful for motion sickness prevention and pre-anesthetic medication. Incorrect Options: (A) Exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye – Incorrect, because hyoscine primarily affects the CNS and gastrointestinal tract, whereas atropine has a stronger cardiac effect by increasing heart rate. Hyoscine does not have a more potent cardiac effect than atropine. (B) Is longer acting – Incorrect, because atropine has a longer duration of action than hyoscine, particularly in ocular applications. Hyoscine's effects are shorter-lived, especially when used for motion sickness. (C) Has weaker antimotion sickness activity – Incorrect, because hyoscine is actually more potent than atropine in preventing motion sickness. It is the drug of choice for motion sickness due to its strong CNS depressant and anti-emetic properties.

choices.text: Blockade of muscarinic auto receptor on vagal nerve endings
Blockade of M2 receptors of SA nodal cells

questions.text: Intramuscular injection of atropine causes initial bradycardia. The reason for this effect being seen is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Blockade of muscarinic autoreceptor on vagal nerve endings. Atropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist, primarily acting on M1, M2, and M3 receptors. When administered intramuscularly (IM), atropine initially causes bradycardia due to its blockade of presynaptic muscarinic (M1) autoreceptors on vagal nerve endings. These autoreceptors normally inhibit acetylcholine (ACh) release, so their blockade leads to a temporary increase in ACh release, resulting in enhanced vagal tone and an initial decrease in heart rate (bradycardia). However, as atropine reaches and blocks M2 receptors in the sinoatrial (SA) node, it inhibits parasympathetic effects, leading to tachycardia. Incorrect Options: (B) Stimulation of medullary vagal center – Incorrect, because atropine is primarily an anticholinergic agent that blocks vagal stimulation rather than stimulating the medullary vagal center. (C) Stimulation of vagal ganglia – Incorrect, as atropine does not stimulate vagal ganglia. Instead, it blocks the effects of vagal stimulation at muscarinic receptors. (D) Blockade of M2 receptors of SA nodal cells – Incorrect, because while M2 receptor blockade eventually causes tachycardia, the initial bradycardia is due to enhanced ACh release from vagal nerve endings, not direct M2 blockade.

questions.text: Lallu, a farmer comes to you in the emergency in comatose state. Patient had profuse sweating and lacrimation. Diarrhea and urination were apparent. On examination pupil was constricted and BP of the farmer was 80/60 mm Hg. You make a diagnosis of anticholinesterase poisoning. You decide to administer him atropine. All of the following actions will be reversed by atropine EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Muscle paralysis. Anticholinesterase poisoning (commonly due to organophosphates found in pesticides) leads to excessive acetylcholine (ACh) accumulation at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors. Atropine, a muscarinic antagonist, effectively reverses most of the muscarinic symptoms, such as bronchoconstriction, bradycardia, excessive sweating, and salivation. However, atropine has no effect on nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, which are responsible for muscle paralysis. Muscle paralysis occurs due to persistent depolarization at the neuromuscular junction, requiring pralidoxime (2-PAM) for reversal. Incorrect Options: (A) Hypotension – Incorrect, because atropine blocks muscarinic vasodilation by inhibiting M3 receptors on endothelial cells, leading to increased vascular tone and improved BP. (B) Central excitation – Incorrect, since atropine crosses the blood-brain barrier and reverses CNS symptoms (e.g., seizures, respiratory depression) caused by excess ACh in the brain. (C) Bronchoconstriction – Incorrect, as atropine blocks M3 receptors in the lungs, leading to bronchodilation, thus reversing the respiratory distress caused by anticholinesterase poisoning.

questions.text: A researcher pharmacologist at AIIMS is interested in creating an anticholinergic agent that would be useful in patients with irritative bladder symptoms would be interested in targeting which of the following receptors?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) M3 Explanation for the Correct Answer: M3 muscarinic receptors are primarily responsible for bladder contraction. These receptors are found on the detrusor muscle of the urinary bladder and are activated by acetylcholine to promote contraction, leading to urination. Patients with irritative bladder symptoms (such as overactive bladder, urgency, frequency, and incontinence) have excessive M3 receptor stimulation, causing involuntary bladder contractions. An anticholinergic agent targeting M3 receptors (e.g., oxybutynin, tolterodine, solifenacin) would reduce detrusor muscle contraction, increase bladder capacity, and relieve urinary urgency and frequency. Thus, the correct answer is (C) M3, as blocking these receptors helps manage irritative bladder symptoms. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: (A) M1 – Incorrect M1 receptors are found in the CNS (brain), gastric glands, and autonomic ganglia. They are involved in cognitive functions, gastric acid secretion, and parasympathetic signaling. Blocking M1 receptors would affect memory and gastric acid secretion, but it would not relieve bladder irritability. (B) M2 – Incorrect M2 receptors are predominantly located in the heart, where they decrease heart rate (negative chronotropic effect). While they are also found in the bladder, their role is less significant compared to M3 receptors in detrusor muscle contraction. Blocking M2 receptors would have cardiac effects rather than improving bladder symptoms. (D) M4 – Incorrect M4 receptors are mainly found in the CNS and play a role in dopaminergic transmission. They are not significantly involved in bladder function, making them an unsuitable target for treating bladder symptoms.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman is on a trip to himachal pradesh, she is fearful that on curvy himalayan highways she will have lot of motion sickness. She presents to a medical officer who gives her scopolamine to take to prevent motion sickness. This agent works in which of the following pathways?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Scopolamine is an antimuscarinic (M receptor) antagonist that primarily works by blocking muscarinic (M1) receptors in the vestibular system and the vomiting center in the brainstem. Motion sickness occurs due to conflicting signals between the inner ear (vestibular system), visual inputs, and proprioceptive cues. The vestibular nuclei project to the vomiting center, where M1 cholinergic receptors play a key role in triggering nausea and vomiting. By blocking these receptors, scopolamine prevents the transmission of these signals, reducing the likelihood of motion sickness. This is why scopolamine is commonly used in the form of a transdermal patch for prophylaxis against motion sickness. Incorrect Options: A. Blockade of β1-receptors β1-adrenergic receptors are found primarily in the heart and kidneys, where they mediate increased heart rate and contractility. β-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are not involved in motion sickness because the vestibular system does not rely on β1 signaling. Blocking β1 receptors would not prevent nausea or dizziness. B. Blockade of β2-receptors β2-adrenergic receptors are primarily found in smooth muscle, including bronchi, vasculature, and the gastrointestinal tract. β2 agonists (like albuterol) cause bronchodilation, while β2 blockers (like propranolol) may induce bronchoconstriction. However, β2 receptors have no direct role in the vestibular pathways involved in motion sickness, making this option incorrect. C. Blockade of H2 receptors H2 receptors are histamine receptors found in the stomach, where they regulate acid secretion. H2 receptor blockers (like ranitidine and famotidine) reduce stomach acid production and are used for conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and peptic ulcers. However, motion sickness is mediated by H1 receptors, not H2 receptors. Antihistamines like meclizine and diphenhydramine (H1 blockers) are sometimes used for motion sickness, but H2 blockers do not play a role in its treatment.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man attempts suicide due to emotional strees, he is brought to the emergency department by the family members. He was found in the store room with an opened spray bottle of insecticide nearby. He has lost consciousness. His heart rate is 45 beats/minute, and his blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. He is sweating and salivating profusely. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Atropine. This patient has organophosphate poisoning, likely from insecticide exposure, which inhibits acetylcholinesterase (AChE), leading to an excess of acetylcholine (ACh) at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors. This results in cholinergic toxicity, characterized by bradycardia, hypotension, excessive sweating, salivation, bronchorrhea, and possible respiratory failure. The mnemonic DUMBBELSS helps recall cholinergic symptoms: D – Diarrhea U – Urination M – Miosis B – Bradycardia B – Bronchospasm E – Emesis L – Lacrimation S – Salivation S – Sweating Atropine, a muscarinic antagonist, is the first-line treatment as it blocks muscarinic receptors, reducing salivation, bronchial secretions, bradycardia, and hypotension. However, atropine does not counteract nicotinic receptor effects (muscle weakness, fasciculations, paralysis). For that, pralidoxime (2-PAM), which regenerates acetylcholinesterase, is also used but should be given early before aging of the enzyme occurs. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (B) Edrophonium: Edrophonium is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis (Tensilon test). It would worsen symptoms in organophosphate poisoning by increasing ACh levels rather than relieving toxicity. (C) Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine is a vasopressor used in hypotension and shock, but it does not address the underlying cause of bradycardia and excessive parasympathetic activity in organophosphate poisoning. It might transiently raise blood pressure, but the fundamental issue—ACh excess—remains unaddressed. (D) Physostigmine: Physostigmine is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases ACh levels and is used to treat anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., atropine overdose). In this case, it would worsen cholinergic toxicity, making symptoms more severe.

questions.text: A 42-year-old traveller is on a road trip in south america when he develops diarrhea. He has to give a presentation in a few hours and needs rapid relief. He takes an antidiarrheal preparation containing loperamide. Which of the following is a property of loperamide that makes it useful in treating diarrhea?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Inhibitor of myenteric plexus activity. Loperamide is an opioid receptor agonist that acts primarily on μ-opioid receptors in the myenteric plexus of the gut. It inhibits the release of acetylcholine and other neurotransmitters, leading to decreased peristalsis and prolonged transit time in the intestines. This allows for increased water absorption, reducing the frequency and urgency of diarrhea. Since loperamide does not cross the blood-brain barrier, it has no central nervous system (CNS) effects, unlike other opioids. This makes it safe for over-the-counter use in managing acute diarrhea, such as traveler’s diarrhea. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Anticholinergic Incorrect because loperamide does not block muscarinic receptors. Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., atropine, diphenoxylate) reduce gut motility by inhibiting acetylcholine activity at muscarinic receptors. While anticholinergics can slow down peristalsis, they are not the primary mechanism of action for loperamide. (B) Broad-spectrum antibiotic Incorrect because loperamide is not an antibiotic. Broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin, azithromycin) treat bacterial infections by killing or inhibiting bacterial growth, but they do not directly affect gut motility. Loperamide is purely symptomatic and does not eliminate the underlying infection. (C) Gram-negative antibiotic Incorrect because loperamide does not act as an antibiotic against Gram-negative bacteria. Many cases of traveler’s diarrhea are caused by Gram-negative bacteria (e.g., E. coli, Salmonella, Shigella), but loperamide does not kill bacteria—it only reduces diarrhea symptoms by slowing gut motility. In some cases of bacterial diarrhea, loperamide is not recommended because slowing motility may prolong infection and toxin exposure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old newly married man with complaint of mild erectile dysfunction presents to the clinic. He has no other medical problems. He does have an anxiety disorder. Physical examination of the abdomen and genitalia are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best agent for treatment of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tadalafil. Tadalafil is a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor used to treat erectile dysfunction (ED) by enhancing the effects of nitric oxide, leading to increased blood flow to the penis. It is preferred in this patient because it has the longest half-life (up to 36 hours) among PDE-5 inhibitors, allowing for greater spontaneity in sexual activity. Unlike sildenafil and vardenafil, which need to be taken shortly before intercourse, tadalafil can be taken once daily at a low dose, making it a convenient choice for younger patients with mild ED. This patient’s young age and history of anxiety suggest that his ED is likely psychogenic, rather than due to an underlying medical condition like diabetes or vascular disease. Tadalafil’s longer duration helps reduce performance anxiety by providing a more natural and sustained response. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Penile prosthesis Incorrect because penile prosthesis is only used for severe, refractory ED that does not respond to medications. This patient has mild ED and is not a candidate for an invasive surgical intervention. (B) Sildenafil Incorrect because sildenafil has a shorter duration of action (4–6 hours) and must be taken just before sexual activity. It is affected by food intake, reducing its effectiveness when taken with fatty meals. Although it is effective, tadalafil is preferred in younger men due to its longer half-life and spontaneity benefits. (D) Vardenafil Incorrect because vardenafil is similar to sildenafil in its duration of action (4–6 hours). Like sildenafil, it requires timing before intercourse, whereas tadalafil allows for a more flexible, spontaneous approach.

choices.text: Blocks uptake of choline into nerve terminals

questions.text: A 40 -year-old actress presents to the dermatologist for treatment to address her wrinkles. She complains that her right eyelid and forehead are “too droopy” and has a persistent head ache since her first Botox treatment 5 days ago. What is the mechanism of action for this treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Prevents release of cholinergic vesicles. Botulinum toxin (Botox) works by inhibiting the release of acetylcholine (ACh) from presynaptic cholinergic neurons at the neuromuscular junction. It does this by cleaving SNARE proteins (e.g., SNAP-25, synaptobrevin, syntaxin), which are essential for vesicular fusion and neurotransmitter release. This prevents muscle contraction, leading to temporary paralysis of facial muscles and smoothing of wrinkles. In this patient, the droopy eyelid (ptosis) and headache are likely due to excess spread of Botox to surrounding muscles, affecting levator palpebrae superioris and causing ptosis. Botox is commonly used in cosmetic dermatology for wrinkle reduction, but improper injection or diffusion of the toxin can cause unintended muscle weakness. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Binds ?-receptors preventing activation Incorrect because botulinum toxin does not act on adrenergic receptors. Drugs that block ?-receptors include alpha blockers (e.g., prazosin, tamsulosin), which are used for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). (B) Binds muscarinic receptors preventing activation Incorrect because Botox does not block muscarinic receptors. Muscarinic antagonists (e.g., atropine, scopolamine, ipratropium) block parasympathetic signaling, but Botox works at the presynaptic level, not on receptors. (C) Blocks uptake of choline into nerve terminals Incorrect because Botox does not interfere with choline transport into neurons. Hemicholinium is a drug that blocks choline uptake, thereby depleting acetylcholine synthesis, but this is not the mechanism of Botox.

questions.text: A 57-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the OPD with complaint of urinary urge incontinence. Medical history is significant for hypertension, which is controlled with losartan. She is not a surgical candidate so pharmacological therapy is chosen to treat her condition, and she begins treatment with solifenacin. Which of the following side effects is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Xerostomia (dry mouth). Solifenacin is an anticholinergic (muscarinic receptor antagonist) that primarily acts on the M3 receptors in the bladder, leading to detrusor muscle relaxation and reduced bladder contractions. This helps treat urge incontinence by increasing bladder storage capacity and reducing involuntary urination. However, M3 receptors are also present in other organs, including the salivary glands. Blocking M3 receptors reduces salivary secretion, leading to xerostomia (dry mouth), which is the most common side effect of solifenacin. Other anticholinergic effects may include constipation, blurred vision (due to mydriasis and cycloplegia), and urinary retention. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Diarrhea Incorrect because solifenacin has the opposite effect—it causes constipation rather than diarrhea. M3 receptors stimulate gastrointestinal motility, so their inhibition leads to decreased peristalsis and delayed bowel movement. Patients on solifenacin may experience constipation, not diarrhea. (B) Hypertension Incorrect because solifenacin does not directly affect blood pressure. Anticholinergics do not cause vasoconstriction or sodium retention, which are mechanisms that contribute to hypertension. Additionally, this patient is already on losartan (an angiotensin receptor blocker or ARB) for hypertension, which would counteract any potential blood pressure effects. (C) Photosensitivity Incorrect because photosensitivity is not a common adverse effect of solifenacin. Photosensitivity reactions are more commonly associated with drugs like tetracyclines, sulfonamides, amiodarone, and thiazide diuretics. Solifenacin does not interfere with melanin production or increase skin sensitivity to UV light.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common side effect of anticholinergic drugs?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dry mouth. Anticholinergic drugs block muscarinic receptors, leading to inhibition of parasympathetic activity. Since salivary gland secretion is under parasympathetic control (mediated by M3 receptors), blocking these receptors reduces saliva production, causing dry mouth (xerostomia). This is one of the most common and clinically significant side effects of anticholinergic drugs, often causing discomfort and difficulty in speaking or swallowing. Incorrect Options: (A) Diarrhea – Incorrect, because anticholinergic drugs decrease gastrointestinal motility and secretions by blocking M3 receptors in the gut. This leads to constipation, not diarrhea. (B) Increased sweating – Incorrect, as sweating is mediated by sympathetic cholinergic fibers acting on muscarinic receptors. Anticholinergic drugs inhibit sweating, leading to anhidrosis (reduced sweating), which can contribute to hyperthermia in hot environments. (D) Bradycardia – Incorrect, since anticholinergic drugs block vagal (parasympathetic) inhibition on the heart. This results in increased heart rate (tachycardia), rather than bradycardia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is prescribed a medication to relieve bronchospasm. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate choice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ipratropium. Ipratropium is an anticholinergic bronchodilator that works by blocking muscarinic receptors (M3) in the airway smooth muscles, leading to bronchodilation. It is particularly effective in COPD because parasympathetic activity contributes significantly to bronchoconstriction in these patients. Ipratropium is often used as a first-line treatment for COPD due to its longer duration of action and minimal systemic side effects compared to β2-agonists. Incorrect Options: (A) Propranolol – Incorrect, because propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker, which can cause bronchoconstriction by blocking β2 receptors in the lungs. This can worsen COPD symptoms and is contraindicated in patients with COPD or asthma. (C) Atenolol – Incorrect, as atenolol is a β1-selective blocker (primarily affecting the heart), but it still has some β2-blocking effects at higher doses. It is not used for COPD treatment and may still exacerbate bronchoconstriction. (D )Clonidine – Incorrect, because clonidine is a centrally acting α2-agonist, used primarily for hypertension. It does not have any bronchodilator effect and is not useful in COPD management.
